Synthetic insecticides may induce resistance in insects
9 , cause toxic reactions in mammals
10 and other non-target organisms such as parasitoids, pollinators, and predators
11– 13 , and may also leave residues
14 and cause environmental pollution
15 . Exposure to insecticide causes adverse effects on the development, longevity and fecundity, and may alter behavior related to mobility and feeding
16– 18 . The search for safer insecticides for human health and the environment has resulted in the development of specific compounds for pests which are selective for non-target organisms
19, 20 . In this sense, effective use of P. nigrispinus in integrated pest management (IPM) programs depends on the compatibility of the predator with the other control methods being employed
21 .
